text: What’s the best way, with flumine, to handle this when both the price and size are to change? Clearly it’s cancel and then place. But if I’m updating too quickly (a feature of my strategy) how do I best avoid a “race” where the order to be cancelled isn’t yet executable (ie. cancellable)?

elements.text: What’s the best way, with flumine, to handle this when both the price and size are to change? Clearly it’s cancel and then place. But if I’m updating too quickly (a feature of my strategy) how do I best avoid a “race” where the order to be cancelled isn’t yet executable (ie. cancellable)?

text: Half answering my own question, I think o need to implement a wait queue for the new order to wait for the cancellation to be confirmed, but that will introduce a lag on placing the updated new order.

elements.text: Half answering my own question, I think o need to implement a wait queue for the new order to wait for the cancellation to be confirmed, but that will introduce a lag on placing the updated new order.

text: How do I confirm an order has been cancelled after market.cancel_order(order)? I think I have a race condition trying the place an order before cancellation. On market that’s not a problem but my strategy requires single live order per runner at any moment, plus need to ensure order has cancelled and not executed (before cancel instruction received).

elements.text: How do I confirm an order has been cancelled after market.cancel_order(order)? I think I have a race condition trying the place an order before cancellation. On market
that’s
not a problem but my strategy requires single live order per runner at any moment, plus need to ensure order has cancelled and not executed (before cancel instruction received).

text:
Hi guys!
Does anybody use *Java* for *orders operations* (place/cancel/update/...)?
What is the best/fastest way to get into - simply implement all API calls by myself or there is something ready I can use?
For Python it's done by _betfairlightweight_, looking for something similar for Java :pray:

elements.text:
Hi guys!
Does anybody use
Java
for
orders operations

(place/cancel/update/...)?
What is the best/fastest way to get into - simply implement all API calls by myself or there is something ready I can use?
For Python it's done by
betfairlightweight
, looking for something similar for Java

text:
There's a list of libraries and applications for different languages here: <https://docs.developer.betfair.com/display/1smk3cen4v3lu3yomq5qye0ni/Sample+Code#SampleCode-ClientLibraries&SampleApplications>

Looks like the Java one hasn't been worked on for a few years, but might be a good starting point for you.

elements.text: There's a list of libraries and applications for different languages here:
Looks like the Java one hasn't been worked on for a few years, but might be a good starting point for you.

text: I've not come across anything in a mature state for Java like BFLW is for Python but this repo has some Java code exanples

elements.text: I've not come across anything in a mature state for Java like BFLW is for Python but this repo has some Java code exanples

text: <https://github.com/betfair/API-NG-sample-code>

attachments.text: Code snippets in various languages to support API-NG client development
attachments.title: betfair/API-NG-sample-code

text: Can't vouch for the quality but if you are dead set on Java it might help you start out.

elements.text: Can't vouch for the quality but if you are dead set on Java it might help you start out.

text: I use Java, and started with the codebase <@UUE6E1LA1>  linked a few years ago. This is the best starting point for Java I'm aware of. Unless you really need a high performance language, I'd recommend going with betfairlightweight. You'll save a lot of time, particularly with getting a backtesting system out of the box.

elements.text: I use Java, and started with the codebase

linked a few years ago. This is the best starting point for Java I'm aware of. Unless you really need a high performance language, I'd recommend going with betfairlightweight. You'll save a lot of time, particularly with getting a backtesting system out of the box.
